'''Ubuntu''' ({{IPAc-en|icon|Ê|Ë|b|Ê|n|t|uË}}<!--the ubuntu.com source has it as "oÇ'boÇntoÅ"-->)<ref>{{cite video |people=Nelson Mandela |date=11 January 2006 |title=The Ubuntu Experience (Nelson Mandela Interview) |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ODQ4WiDsEBQ |medium=Motion picture}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ubuntu.com/project/about-ubuntu |title=About Ubuntu |publisher=Ubuntu.com |date= |accessdate=2011-05-27}}</ref> is a computer [[operating system]] based on the [[Debian|Debian GNU/Linux]] [[Linux distribution|distribution]] and distributed as [[free and open source software]]. It is named after the [[Southern Africa]]n philosophy of ''[[Ubuntu (philosophy)|Ubuntu]]'' ("humanity towards others").<ref>{{cite web |url=https://help.ubuntu.com/10.10/about-ubuntu/C/about-ubuntu-name.html |title=About the Name |work=Official Ubuntu Documentation |publisher=Canonical |accessdate=8 November 2010}}</ref>
+
'''Ubuntu''' ({{IPAc-en|icon|Ê|Ë|b|Ê|n|t|uË}}<!--the ubuntu.com source has it as "oÇ'boÇntoÅ"-->)<ref>{{cite video |people=Nelson Mandela |date=11 January 2006 |title=The Ubuntu Experience (Nelson Mandela Interview) |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ODQ4WiDsEBQ |medium=Motion picture}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ubuntu.com/project/about-ubuntu |title=About Ubuntu |publisher=Ubuntu.com |date= |accessdate=2011-05-27}}</ref> is a computer [[operating system]] based on the [[Debian]] [[Linux distribution|distribution]] and distributed as [[free and open source software]]. It is named after the [[Southern Africa]]n philosophy of ''[[Ubuntu (philosophy)|Ubuntu]]'' ("humanity towards others").<ref>{{cite web |url=https://help.ubuntu.com/10.10/about-ubuntu/C/about-ubuntu-name.html |title=About the Name |work=Official Ubuntu Documentation |publisher=Canonical |accessdate=8 November 2010}}</ref>
Ubuntu is designed primarily for use on [[personal computer]]s, although a [[Server (computing)|server]] edition also exists. Ubuntu holds an estimated global usage of more than 20 million<!--desktop--> users,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computerworlduk.com/news/operating-systems/3310952/canonical-launches-ubuntu-1110-update/?page=0,0 |title=Canonical launches Ubuntu 11.10 update |publisher=Computerworld UK |date=14 October 2011 |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> making it the most popular desktop Linux distribution<ref>{{cite web|url=http://distrowatch.com/stats.php?section=popularity|title=Linux Distributions - Facts and Figures|publisher=distrowatch.com|accessdate=26 April 2011}}</ref> with about 50% of [[Linux desktop]] marketshare.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://statowl.com/operating_system_market_share_by_os_version.php?1=1&timeframe=last_6&interval=month&chart_id=4&fltr_br=&fltr_os=&fltr_se=&fltr_cn=&limit%5B%5D=linux |title=Operating System Version Usage |publisher=statowl.com |accessdate=29 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://stats.wikimedia.org/wikimedia/squids/SquidReportOperatingSystems.htm |title=Wikimedia Visitor Log Analysis Report - Operating Systems |publisher=Wikimedia |accessdate=11 December 2009}}</ref> It is fourth most popular on web servers,<ref>{{cite web|last=Gelbmann|first=Matthias|title=Highlights of web technology surveys, February 2011: Ubuntu increases its market share on web servers|url=http://w3techs.com/blog/entry/highlights_of_web_technology_surveys_february_2011|publisher=w3Techs|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> and its popularity is increasing rapidly.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://trends.builtwith.com/Server/Ubuntu|title=Ubuntu Usage Statistics |publisher=builtwith.com |accessdate=19 April 2010}}</ref>
Ubuntu is designed primarily for use on [[personal computer]]s, although a [[Server (computing)|server]] edition also exists. Ubuntu holds an estimated global usage of more than 20 million<!--desktop--> users,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computerworlduk.com/news/operating-systems/3310952/canonical-launches-ubuntu-1110-update/?page=0,0 |title=Canonical launches Ubuntu 11.10 update |publisher=Computerworld UK |date=14 October 2011 |accessdate=18 October 2011}}</ref> making it the most popular desktop Linux distribution<ref>{{cite web|url=http://distrowatch.com/stats.php?section=popularity|title=Linux Distributions - Facts and Figures|publisher=distrowatch.com|accessdate=26 April 2011}}</ref> with about 50% of [[Linux desktop]] marketshare.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://statowl.com/operating_system_market_share_by_os_version.php?1=1&timeframe=last_6&interval=month&chart_id=4&fltr_br=&fltr_os=&fltr_se=&fltr_cn=&limit%5B%5D=linux |title=Operating System Version Usage |publisher=statowl.com |accessdate=29 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://stats.wikimedia.org/wikimedia/squids/SquidReportOperatingSystems.htm |title=Wikimedia Visitor Log Analysis Report - Operating Systems |publisher=Wikimedia |accessdate=11 December 2009}}</ref> It is fourth most popular on web servers,<ref>{{cite web|last=Gelbmann|first=Matthias|title=Highlights of web technology surveys, February 2011: Ubuntu increases its market share on web servers|url=http://w3techs.com/blog/entry/highlights_of_web_technology_surveys_february_2011|publisher=w3Techs|accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> and its popularity is increasing rapidly.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://trends.builtwith.com/Server/Ubuntu|title=Ubuntu Usage Statistics |publisher=builtwith.com |accessdate=19 April 2010}}</ref>
